[docs]class screen_session(object):


[docs]    def __init__(self, hostname, oob_addr):
        self.hostname = hostname
        self.oob_addr = oob_addr
        self.ipmi_command = ('ipmitool -I lanplus -U'
                ' USERID -P PASSW0RD -H %s' % (self.oob_addr))

        os.system("screen -S %s -X quit" % (hostname))
        os.system("screen -dmS %s -L" % (hostname))



[docs]    def start_sol(self):
        # `echo -ne '#'` is sending a key input
        # through screen to execute a command in
        # the screen session
        # all input translation codes for the GNU
        # screen found here:
        # https://www.gnu.org/software/screen/manual/html_node/Input-Translation.html
        # \015 is enter, \033 is ESC, \033[B is down
        os.system(
                 ('screen -S %s -p 0 -X stuff "%s'
                 % (self.hostname, self.ipmi_command)
                 + " sol deactivate `echo -ne '\015'`\""))
        os.system(
                'screen -S %s -p 0 -X stuff "%s'
                % (self.hostname, self.ipmi_command) +
                " sol activate `echo -ne '\015'`\"")



[docs]    def end_sol(self):
        os.system(
                 ('screen -S %s -p 0 -X stuff "%s'
                 % (self.hostname, self.ipmi_command)
                 + " sol deactivate `echo -ne '\015'`\""))



[docs]    def exit_bios(self):
        os.system("screen -S %s -p 0 -X stuff `echo -ne '\033'`"
                 % (self.hostname))
        time.sleep(3)
        os.system("screen -S %s -p 0 -X stuff `echo -ne '\015'`"
                % (self.hostname))



[docs]    def end_session(self):
        os.system("screen -S %s -X quit" % (self.hostname))



[docs]class System_Time_Update(TestBase):


[docs]    def reboot_into_bios(self):
        self.host.run("echo r > /proc/sysrq-trigger")
        self.host.oob.run_ipmicmd("raw 0x00 0x08 0x03 0x08")
        self.host.oob.run_ipmicmd(
                "chassis bootdev bios options=persistent")
        self.host.oob.run_ipmicmd("power reset")



[docs]    def disable_chef_temporarily(self):
        self.host.run('/usr/facebook/ops/scripts/chef/stop_chef_temporarily')



[docs]    def execute(self):

        self.log_info("This is the system time update test")
        hostname = self.hosts[0]['hostname']
        oob_addr = self.hosts[0]['oob_addr']
        self.disable_chef_temporarily()

        bmc_time = datetime.strptime(
                ''.join(
                    ''.join(
                        ''.join(self.host.oob.run_ipmicmd("sel time get")
                            .split()).split("/")).split(":")), "%m%d%Y%H%M%S")

        system_time = datetime.strptime(
                ''.join(self.host.run("date +%m%d%Y%H%M%S --utc")),
                "%m%d%Y%H%M%S")

        # keep checking if bmc time is same as system time, if so
        # add three days to system time. We want bmc time and system
        # time to be different.
        # %m%d%Y are date format specifiers, ex. 07/28/2015
        # more date format specifiers found here:
        # http://www.cyberciti.biz/faq/linux-unix-formatting-dates-for-display/

        if math.fabs((system_time - bmc_time).total_seconds() // 3600) <= 24:
            system_time = datetime.strptime(
                ''.join(self.host.run("date -s '+3 days' +%m%d%Y%H%M%S --utc")),
                "%m%d%Y%H%M%S")

        self.validate_condition(
            math.fabs((system_time - bmc_time).total_seconds() // 3600)
            >= 48,
            "system time and bmc time are at least 2 days apart")

        # update rtc time to system time
        self.host.run("hwclock --systohc")

        rtc_test_time = datetime.strptime(
                ''.join(
                    ''.join(
                        self.host.run("hwclock --local")
                        .split()[:6]).split(":")), "%a%d%b%Y%I%M%S%p")

        # ensure rtc has been updated to system time
        # rtc has natural drift in time, unsure how big that
        # drift is, but giving a day buffer to validate
        # rtc clock has been updated to system clock
        self.validate_condition(
            math.fabs((system_time - rtc_test_time).total_seconds() // 3600)
            <= 24,
            "rtc and system clock are within are within a day from eachother")

        # start screen session and start sol to monitor host as it boots up
        screen_sess = screen_session(hostname, oob_addr)
        screen_sess.start_sol()

        # restart host and boot into bios
        self.reboot_into_bios()

        # wait a long enough time for system to enter bios
        time.sleep(400)

        # get the latest screen. Terminal output is in
        # unicode because we imported unicode_literals for
        # compliance with python 3. So we have to decode it
        # to our file system's encoding, and we ignore
        # any characters that our file system's encoding
        # can't recognize.
        new_file = os.popen('tail -n 1 screenlog.0 ' +
                 '| sed -r "s/\x1B\\[([0-9]{1,2}(;[0-9]{1,2})?)?[m|K]//g"')\
                 .read()\
                 .decode(sys.getfilesystemencoding(), 'ignore')

        # parse out date and time, this will break when bios UI changes
        # regex's below are looking at the bios screen, snippet shown
        # below
        #
        # | System Date                  [Fri 07/24/2015]      * |
        # | System Time                  [19:00:28]            * |
        date_regex = re.compile(
                r'\[(?P<word_day>\D{3}) (?P<date_s>\d{2}[/]+\d\d[/]+\d{4})\]')
        time_regex = re.compile(r'(?P<hour>\d\d):(?P<minute>\d\d):\d\d\]')

        find_system_time = filter(lambda x: 'System Time' in x,
                        new_file.split('|'))
        find_system_date = filter(lambda x: 'System Date' in x,
                           new_file.split('|'))

        # Scroll down the bios screen until we see a line with
        # 'system time' and 'system date'. If we scrolled down
        # 100 times and still can't find it, fail the test,
        # because otherwise it'll just infinitely loop
        # example of what we are parsing out:
        #
        # | System Date                  [Fri 07/24/2015]      * |
        # | System Time                  [19:00:28]            * |
        # note: If BIOS UI changes so we no longer have System
        # time and system date in the format it's currently
        # specified this will break, but i can't think of a way
        # around it, because parsing out strings.

        for dead_count in range(0, 100):
            if 0 in (len(find_system_time), len(find_system_date)):
                os.system(
                        "screen -S %s -p 0 -X stuff `echo -ne '\033[B'`"
                        % (hostname))
                new_file = os.popen('tail -n 1 screenlog.0 | ' +
                        'sed -r "s/\x1B\\[([0-9]{1,2}(;[0-9]{1,2})?)?[m|K]//g"')\
                        .read()\
                        .decode(sys.getfilesystemencoding(), 'ignore')
                find_system_time = filter(lambda x: 'System Time' in x,
                        new_file.split('|'))
                find_system_date = filter(lambda x: 'System Date' in x,
                           new_file.split('|'))
                time.sleep(10)
                dead_count += 1
            else:
                self.validate_condition(
                        len(filter(time_regex.search,
                            filter(lambda x: 'System Time' in x,
                                new_file.split('|')))) > 0,
                            "We found a system time")

                the_time = time_regex.search(
                    filter(time_regex.search,
                        filter(lambda x: 'System Time' in x,
                            new_file.split('|')))[0])

                self.validate_condition(
                    len(filter(date_regex.search,
                        filter(
                            lambda x: 'System Date' in x,
                            new_file.split('|')))) > 0,
                    "We found a system date")

                date_time = date_regex.search(
                    filter(date_regex.search,
                           filter(lambda x: 'System Date' in x,
                                  new_file.split('|')))[0])

                bios_time = datetime.strptime(
                        ''.join(date_time.group('date_s').split("/"))
                        + the_time.group('hour') + the_time.group('minute'),
                        "%m%d%Y%H%M")

                # comparison of bios time and system time,
                # see if they are a day within eachother
                # if so, we know it was not changed by the
                # bmc, so pass the test.
                self.validate_condition(
                    (math.fabs((system_time - bios_time)
                        .total_seconds() // 3600)) <= 24,
                    "clock was not changed by bmc")

                # clean up by restarting host,
                # deactivating sol connection and killing the screen session
                screen_sess.exit_bios()
                screen_sess.end_sol()
                screen_sess.end_session()
                exit(0)

        self.log_info("We never found a system time and system date in bios")

    test = System_Time_Update()
    test.lifecycle()


if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()
